item.title: Maureen add a quote by Anonymous
item.description: "Live a good life. If there are gods and they are just, then they will not care how devout you have been, but will welcome you based on the virtues you have lived by. If there are gods, but unjust, then you should not want to worship them. If there are no gods, then you will be gone, but will have lived a noble life that will live on in the memories of your loved ones." -- Anonymous

item.title: Maureen add a quote by George Etherege
item.description: "Love gilds us over and makes us show fine things to one another for a time, but soon the gold wears off, and then again the native brass appears." -- George Etherege

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Jorge Luis Borges
item.description: "The mind was dreaming. The world was its dream." -- Jorge Luis Borges

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Margaret Laurence
item.description: "So, if this were indeed my Final Hour, these would be my words to you. I would not claim to pass on any secret of life, for there is none, or any wisdom except the passionate plea of caring ... Try to feel, in your heart's core, the reality of others. This is the most painful thing in the world, probably, and the most necessary. In times of personal adversity, know that you are not alone. Know that although in the eternal scheme of things you are small, you are also unique and irreplaceable, as are all of your fellow humans everywhere in the world. Know that your commitment is above all to life itself." -- Margaret Laurence

item.title: Maureen add a quote by George Sanders
item.description: "Dear World, I am leaving because I am bored. I feel I have lived long enough. I am leaving you with your worries in this sweet cesspool. Good luck." -- George Sanders

item.title: Maureen add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "There is no surer foundation for a beautiful friendship than a mutual taste in literature." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Marcel Proust
item.description: "Every reader, as he reads, is actually the reader of himself. The writer's work is only a kind of optical instrument he provides the reader so he can discern what he might never have seen in himself without this book. The reader's recognition in himself of what the book says is the proof of the book's truth." -- Marcel Proust

item.title: Maureen add a quote by C.S. Lewis
item.description: "Friendship is born at that moment when one man says to another: "What! You too? I thought that no one but myself . . .&#34;" -- C.S. Lewis

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Dashiell Hammett
item.description: "I first heard Personville called Poisonville by a red-haired mucker named Hickey Dewey in the Big Ship in Butte. He also called his shirt a shoit." -- Dashiell Hammett

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Philip K. Dick
item.description: "The true measure of a man is not his intelligence or how high he rises in this freak establishment. No, the true measure of a man is this: how quickly can he respond to the needs of others and how much of himself he can give." -- Philip K. Dick

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Robertson Davies
item.description: "Conversation in its true meaning isn't all wagging the tongue; sometimes it is a deeply shared silence. " -- Robertson Davies

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Berkeley Breathed
item.description: "I will go to my grave in a state of abject endless fascination that we all have the capacity to become emotionally involved with a personality that doesn't exist." -- Berkeley Breathed

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Henry James
item.description: "Three things in human life are important: the first is to be kind; the second is to be kind; and the third is to be kind." -- Henry James

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Jonathan Carroll
item.description:
"Part of life is a quest to find that one essential person who will understand our story. But we choose wrongly so often. Over the ensuing years that person we thought understood us best ends up regarding us with pity, indifference, or active dislike.
Those who truly care can be divided into two categories: those who understand us, and those who forgive our worst sins. Rarely do we find someone capable of both." -- Jonathan Carroll

item.title: Maureen add a quote by G.K. Chesterton
item.description: "Poets have been mysteriously silent on the subject of cheese." -- G.K. Chesterton

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Marcus Aurelius
item.description: "Though you break your heart, men will go on as before." -- Marcus Aurelius

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Billy Sunday
item.description: "Going to church doesn’t make you a Christian any more than going to a garage makes you an automobile." -- Billy Sunday

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Neil Gaiman
item.description: "Fairy tales are more than true: not because they tell us that dragons exist, but because they tell us that dragons can be beaten." -- Neil Gaiman

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Jonathan Carroll
item.description: "Reading a book, for me at least, is like traveling in someone else's world. If it's a good book, then you feel comfortable and yet anxious to see what's going to happen to you there, what'll be around the next corner. But if it's a lousy book, then it's like going through Secaucus, New Jersey -- it smells and you wish you weren't there, but since you've started the trip, you roll up the windows and breathe through your mouth until you're done." -- Jonathan Carroll

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Ralph Waldo Emerson
item.description: "A friend is a person with whom I may be sincere. Before him I may think aloud. I am arrived at last in the presence of a man so real and equal, that I may drop even those undermost garments of dissimulation, courtesy, and second thought, which men never put off, and may deal with him with the simplicity and wholeness with which one chemical atom meets another." -- Ralph Waldo Emerson

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Ben Loory
item.description: "Until finally he sees-- as it lies all around him-- the truth: it is space that makes stars." -- Ben Loory

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Oscar Wilde
item.description: "I am so clever that sometimes I don't understand a single word of what I am saying." -- Oscar Wilde

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Willa Cather
item.description: "The idea of you is a part of my mind; you influence my likes and dislikes, all my tastes, hundreds of times when I don't realize it. You really are a part of me. In the course of twenty crowded years one parts with many illusions. I did not wish to lose the early ones. Some memories are realities, and are better than anything that can ever happen again." -- Willa Cather

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Robertson Davies
item.description: "The gift that isn't big enough to make a mark, but is too big to leave the possessor in peace. And so they can't be content to be Sunday painters, or poets who write for a few friends, or composers whose handful of delicate little settings of Emily Dickinson can't find a singer. It's a special sort of hell." -- Robertson Davies

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Willa Cather
item.description: "I have sometimes thought that his bursts of imaginative talk were fatal to his poetic gift. He squandered too much in the heat of personal communication." -- Willa Cather

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Marcus Aurelius
item.description: "Dwell on the beauty of life. Watch the stars, and see yourself running with them." -- Marcus Aurelius

item.title: Maureen add a quote by T.E. Brown
item.description: "If thou could'st empty all thyself of self, like to a shell dishabited, then might He find thee on the ocean shelf, and say "This is not dead," and fill thee with Himself instead. But thou art all replete with very thou and hast such shrewd activity, that when He comes He says, "This is enow unto itself-'twere better let it be, it is so small and full, there is no room for Me." -- T.E. Brown

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Jonathan Carroll
item.description: "One of the saddest realities is that we never know when our lives are at their peak. Only after it is over and we have some kind of perspective do we realize how good we had it a day, a month, five years ago. " -- Jonathan Carroll

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Mario Vargas-Llosa
item.description: "Writers are the exorcists of their own demons." -- Mario Vargas-Llosa

item.title: Maureen add a quote by Madeleine L'Engle
item.description: "You have to write the book that wants to be written. And if the book will be too difficult for grown-ups, then you write it for children." -- Madeleine L'Engle
